awd_titl_txt: CRII: SaTC: Discerning the Upgradeability of Smart Contracts in Blockchains From a Security Perspective
awd_abstract_narration:
Smart contracts in blockchains, which store cryptocurrencies and tokens worth billions of USD, have transformed many important aspects of our lives, such as finance and gaming. Smart contracts are widely believed to have strong security guarantees as they are immutable once deployed, not even the owner of the contract can change its code. However, a new type of smart contract, namely upgradeable smart contract (USC), allows developers to upgrade the logic of their smart contracts and practically breaks the security assumption. This special type of smart contract has become increasingly prominent and has been adopted by many major companies (e.g., Compound Finance and Opensea.io). Despite the importance, there exists no comprehensive research that studies the status quo of USCs in the wild and even worse, the emerging security risks that are associated with upgradeability. This project conducts a series of novel studies to discern the upgradeability of smart contracts in the real world. Specifically, it answers three essential research questions regarding the importance of USCs in the current market, different design patterns and their strengths and weaknesses, and more importantly, the real-world security risks with USCs. 

To do so, this project pioneers a practical static analysis-based approach to effectively detect USCs based on intrinsic characteristics, and perform further automatic behavior and security analyses. To differentiate USC design patterns, this project develops a complete taxonomy that can systematically characterize USCs at both syntactic and semantic levels. Moreover, the investigator conducts the first extensive and large-scale study on USCs to uncover and report unique designs and security risks in the real world. Eventually, this project creates the first comprehensive USC dataset that facilitates future research in this emerging direction.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on improving blockchain security by addressing vulnerabilities in smart contracts and decentralized applications. It introduced new techniques for securing upgradeable contracts, detecting logic errors introduced during upgrades, and strengthening off-chain message signing practices.

 

The research developed multiple practical tools, including USCHUNT, a static analyzer that can detect and analyze upgradeable smart contracts, DIFFUSC, a differential fuzzing tool to detect logic errors in smart contract upgrades, and SigScope, an automated analysis framework for identifying security flaws in off-chain message signing. These tools provided innovative, automated approaches for detecting vulnerabilities that traditional methods often miss. The findings contribute to improving blockchain security best practices, benefiting developers, financial institutions, and policymakers working to secure decentralized finance (DeFi) platforms.

 

The project uncovered weaknesses in how upgradeable smart contracts are managed, highlighting risks related to unauthorized modifications and security gaps in upgrade processes. DIFFUSC was successfully tested on real-world projects, demonstrating its ability to identify critical logic errors that could lead to financial losses. SigScope revealed widespread vulnerabilities in off-chain message signing, showing how weak implementations could be exploited for unauthorized transactions. The findings were published in leading security and blockchain conferences, influencing best practices and security standards in the industry.

 

This project significantly advanced blockchain security by introducing new methodologies for vulnerability detection, improving the safety of smart contract upgrades, and securing decentralized applications. Its contributions help strengthen the security of blockchain ecosystems, reduce risks for developers and users, and shape future research and policy discussions on securing decentralized finance.
